node.title: Queenslanders will be able to ditch masks once vaccination rate hits 80 per cent first dose
node.alt: The premier begins to take off her mask.
node.description: Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk has announced masks will no longer be required when 80 per cent of eligible Queenslanders over 16 years of age have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.
node.content:
["Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk has announced masks will no longer be required when 80 per cent\u00a0of eligible Queenslanders over 16 years of age\u00a0have received at least one dose of a COVID-19 vaccine.", "After first tweeting the announcement this morning, the Premier has now released a statement saying people will be able to pack away their masks \"the minute\" the state reaches that target, with one good roll-up today meaning the state could be mask-free by tomorrow.\u00a0", "\"This is another small step back towards life as normal,\" the Premier said.", "\"Queenslanders have done an incredible job all through the pandemic and this is their reward.", "\"The more of us who are vaccinated, the faster we return to life the way it used to be.", "\"That means life without the need to wear masks, except at airports and on planes.\"", "People will not need to wear masks indoors, including at schools, workplaces, cafes, pubs, clubs\u00a0and hairdressers.", "Under federal rules, masks need to remain mandatory in airports and planes.", "They are also strongly recommended for public transport and places where people cannot socially distance anywhere across Queensland.", "Queensland's first dose vaccination rate currently sits at 79.6 per cent, while 67.4 per cent\u00a0people are fully immunised.", "Authorities said they expect the state to hit the 80 per cent milestone either today or tomorrow.", "A significant push will be needed to surpass 80 per cent\u00a0today after the first dose rate increased by just 0.1 per cent\u00a0on Monday.", "Health Minister Yvette D'Ath said Queenslanders shouldn't throw them away just yet.", "\"We have no community cases and, therefore, no need to wear masks in most settings,\" Ms D'Ath\u00a0said.", "\"But we shouldn't throw them away.", "\"Masks have been an excellent defence against the spread of COVID and it's more than likely we will need them again.\"", "", "
Outbreak: How Australia lost control of the Delta variant
"]
